name: Little painted desert
description:
Informal campground with a wonderful view at the sunset on the Little painted desert.
Good LTE with Tmobile. 
Several fire pits

name: Flying J
description: Truck stop. All the amenities you could ask for. There is a Denny’s inside. Plus hot food and dessert options from flying j. Bathrooms, of course gas and snacks. Shower and laundry for a price - I didn’t check it out. A decent parking lot. I parked along the back grassy area. I heard a couple trains before I fell asleep. About 6 RV spots available as well.

name: Hopi Cultural Center
description:
At the parking of Cultural Center and restaurant, on the left, there is an area with many places to camp. Lot of camper already here but many places to sleep. Close to the highway, a little noisy but it’s ok. The road is very easy.
You can pitch your tent.
It’s free.

name: Maverik
description:
Free water and dump station. Lots of room to turn around, and cheap gas. Water is in between the pumps in the ‘truck/RV’ area.
Free air station at the Truck area.

name: Standing on the Corner

name: Flying J, Winslow

Truck stop and rest area. Potable water is available on a blue stand pipe to the left of the car/RV entrance. Plenty of room and a hose provided.
dumping $10. 
Water Free to use

name: Homolovi State Park
description:
About 2 miles NE of Winslow, easy access off I-40. Remarkably quiet, open, spacious, clean showers/toilet, well maintained by Arizona Parks.
$18 for dry camping. Full hook ups available too, plenty of sites, all with picnic benches fire pits & paved with small trees & shrubs between sites
Seems a lot of folks have found this spot to overnight in.

description: Big dirt lot right next to the library and police station. Park in lower sectionof lot. I stayed 3 nights with no issues (the local sheriff did like my 69 VW Bus tho). Decent Wifi from the library. There's two laundromats in town and a small grocery. Some noise from the interstate and trains but overall not too bad.

name: Arizona Welcome Center I-40
description:
Nice rest area, recently re-opened, super clean!

Restrooms are heated and very clean. Water is hot in the sinks, air is hot coming out of the dryers.

Clean water available outside at fountains and also spigots (2) just to the west of the restrooms (you'll see signs about conserving water).

Lots of covered picnic benches, great scenery around, shops just down the road if you want a bite to eat or souvenirs, ample parking.

There is a train that runs often on the other sidenof the highway and they blow their horn every time because of a railroad crossing, but if you're a sound sleeper, it's no big deal.

Lots of parking, some are more level than others (especially at the very end spots that look to the rock west).

Quite a few vending machines too for snacks and sodas.

Room for pets to roam around as well!

name: Arizona welcome center
description: You have to come off 40 to access this rest area, but there are a couple spigots that say "conserve water." They are only designed for container filling.

name: Navajo Travel Stop (Shell)
description: Travel stop with bathrooms, a Subway and two lots for trucks/ RV parking!

name: Petrified forest National Park
description: brand new dump at the Chinde picnic site within Petrified Forest National Park. Free to use, to get there you need to enter the National Park (25 dollar or free with America the Beautiful pass)

name: Bowl Canyon Lake
description:
We have been traveling around the Four Corners area for 20 years and didn't know this place existed.  A very nice, quiet campground on a lake.  The sign said $15/night, but the booth was not manned so there was noone to pay.  7800 ft elevation means it is cool in the summer.  Two entrances, the north for a picnic area and south for camping.  No services.  
Unfortunately, some local hoodlums arrived at 1am and howled at the moon all night.  They made us very uncomfortable so we left at dawn.

name: El Morro National Monument Campground
description:
El Morro National Monument operates a nine-site campground year-round. Each site has a graveled tent pad, picnic table and ground grill for fires. During the warmer months, water is available in spigots.  You are not allowed to fill up your RV at this site.  Once the overnight low's begin to reach freezing temperatures, water is turned off for the season. There are no hookups for RVs. The length limit on all motor homes is 27 feet overall. One site, #5, is handicapped accessible.

Sites are available by self-registration on a first-come, first-served basis (reservations not accepted). The campground occasionally fills-up on weekends from May through September. El Morro National Monument no longer collects camping fees. Campsites are fee free. The site is regularly patrolled by NPS Police.   The closest town is Grant NM.  

Fires are permitted in provided grills only. Please comply with any seasonal fire restrictions. Collection of firewood within the monument is prohibited, so bring firewood with you if you intend to have a campfire.

description: Nice spot just off the road. Look for a parking lot on the left soon after you enter Cibola NF. Just went up a road (we are in 2wd VW Eurovan) that leaves from the side of the parking lot. Beautiful spot, not trashed like the lower dirt pull offs you see immediately upon entering the NF. Lots more farther up too, I’m guessing.

name: Six Mile Canyon
description: GPS is 2 5 miles from Flying J at exit 39 on I40.  Dirt road great until going past forest service gate and goes down rapidly in quality. name: Pullout near the highway
description: It is a nice spot for one night... some road noise, but peaceful. Gorgeous view of the mountains, and decent cell service. Good enough for me.

name: Hilltop In Cibola
description: Several pine covered spots on hilltop overlooking pastures. 4-5 level spots with fire rings. Lots of broken glass in fire rings. Prior campers didn’t pack out their trash and typical epidemic of toilet paper everywhere. Cooler here than any surrounding spots. Strawberry Canyon hike nearby. Recommended.

name: USA RV Park
description:
RV park with lots of level pull through spots. Front desk is very helpful, with easy checkin. This is a great place to stay long term if you plan on doing any climbing at Mentmore, or if you are just passing through.

It is worth noting that this park is about a mile or so from a municipal airport and you do get the occasional (very) low flying plane passing overhead. This didn't happen frequently, but I did get woken up one night around 2am thinking a tornado was passing by.

2-3 bars of Verizon 4g

Oh, and you should definitely get donuts from Westend Donut + Deli across. the street!

description: Free dump if you fill up with gas. Dump station is close to the road in front of the store. Sign says “buy 30 gallons of gas for free dump”. I only filled up 15 gallons of gas and they didn’t charge me so just ask.

name: Pullout before Cibola
description: Huge gravel pullout just off the highway on your way to Cibola National Forest. Three bars on T-Mobile. Not much highway noise. No one bothered me. Beautiful view of the mountains.

name: Maverick Road
description: We tried to stay at the east bound rest area back several miles on June 28 2021 but it was closed. I looked on google maps app and this looked like a place we could get in and turn around and get headed back out off, we are about 65 foot total length when 'toading' (a word I just made up). This appears to have been an old small truck stop many many years ago as you can see where the old fuel island was. It is a good gravel lot and solid to drive on. It has been used by trucker and RVer's many times. There is a little road noise from I-40 but not bad. It is just an empty parking lot. The entrance is bumpy so just go slow. We will stay there again when passing through. I even took time in the morning to adjust my front wheel bearing as I thought it was a little tight. I had just cleaned and repacked them 600 miles before that, it turn out that it didn't need adjusting but better to check and have all be good.

name: Gallup OHV/ATV facility
description: There are no signs saying' no camping' but they do say 'no dumping'.  There are a few picnic tables and pit toilets but nothing else.  Quite large.  Could be busy on weekends with ATVs.  5G TMobile.  Dirt roads so not sure about conditions if it's wet.

name: Car Wash
description: Car wash with plenty of height RV’s. Just in time to get all the salt, mud, bugs off.

name: Multiple dirt pull off of 400

Low traffic, and good cover from surrounding trees. No signage of any kind.

name: Showers, laundry and water

name: Cibola ridge line

un endroit simple sur un terrain vague. Pour une nuit gratuite très bien,calme .

name: CdC National Monument
description: A rough two track road in the Monument. 4WD recommended. Not sure if it's OK to camp here or not. There were no signs indicating otherwise. Peaceful. Awoke to the snorting of wild horses.

name: Sand Pit near Canyon de Chelly
description: CAREFUL: WHOLE AREA IS A SAND PIT. YOU MIGHT GET STUCK. Just outside entrance of Canyon de Chelly, among a few trees and near the river.  A bit of road noise, but does quiet down at night.  Would not venture in with wet weather as ground appears to get very soft and flood.  No one bothered us, and shade from the trees.  Level, and good AT&T LTE.

name: Four Corners
description: Stand at the intersection of 4 states!  $5 entry per person. Free for 6 years & under.

name: Teec Nos Pos Commercial Inspection Station
description:
Got stuck out in the middle of nowhere. Not many options for overnighting out here - maybe none. We know big trucks park for the night at Inspection stations, so why not a camper van. The station was closed at night but security lighting is on. I parked half out of sight around back.

Had an uneventful night, so a good sleep. Very little traffic. No trucks pulled in that we know of.

name: Bisti BLM parking
description:
Gravel lot    Bisti Badlands parking lot. Free, very quiet except for the cyotes! 
Lots of great badlands formations.

name: Bisti Badlands - Parking north
description:
Parking north of Bisti Badlands. 
No amenities. 
The dirty road to join the other informal campsite of Bisti Badlands is cut, use the main road.

name: Walmart Farmington
description: Big parking lot. Very quiet at night. A few rv's around. Shop is open 24/7.

name: Bisti Wilderness
description: Camping in the beautiful Bisti Badlands at the end of the road ca 1 mile past the two parking lots for Bisti Wilderness. Nice view, quiet. You can camp at the Bisti Trailhead but there will be a lot more campers.

name: La Plata Badlands
description: Free Camping at La Plata Badlands north of Farmington near Jackson Lake Wildlife Management Area. The Dirtroad leads to several Oil and Gas Stations and is in good shape. The place is surrounded by badlands and would be nice, but there is quite a lot rubbish around.

name: Burnham Badlands
description: Wild Camping on Navajo Tribal Land along Indian Service Road 5080 at the Trailhead to Burnham Badlands. The view across the badlands to Shiprock is absolutely gorgeous but wild camping on Indian Reservations is always a bit tricky because you are not really on public land. We had a nice talk with a woman living some hundred yards away, so it was ok to stay here over night.

name: Lake Farmington Recreation Area
description: This spot is awesome!  Each area has a shaded picnic area, grill, and a fire pit. Spots are tucked in by cinder blocks making them feel very private. Clean pit toilets. Excellent cell service. You’re overlooking a small man made Lake that supports fishing and bathing.  Strictly dry camping but the rate can’t be beat.  $5.00 per vehicle with toad plus $1.00 per person.

name: Off Again 4x4
description: After destroying my rear driveshaft while wheeling in New Mexico, I stumbled upon Off Again and they were able to build me a new driveshaft with all new spicer joints for with the same quality and price as any of the mail order companies in the US like Tom Woods or Adams. They also were very reasonable with some aftermarket parts for my rig. I don’t live anywhere near here but they gained a customer for life.

name: Lake Farmington RV Park

Boating and beach swimming at the lakefront.  $5.00 per day plus $1.00 per person fees.  You can call for reservations or walk up, no problem. description:
There were quite a fee cehicles at Muley Point so we took this rught turn before the point and came to another point on the rim that was just as beautiful but secluded.  you need some clearance to get back here, but not 4x4.

We got a weak GSM roaming signal, but our friens with Verizion bounced from nothing to 4 bars of 4G.

no ammenities at all; just great views.

name: Fire pit wild camping
description: Wild camp site between Capital Reef and Lake Mead

name: Colorado River Rimming near Hite
description: Pull off road on eastern side of bridge to the left if travelling east. Hide car behind the rock wall. We camped a level down from road outside of view. rock fire pit  no shade but amaaazing views. can scramble down to the river a little upstream from bridge. some bridge/road noise but not all night and not heavy. make sure to stop at Hite overlook on west side of bridge for another epic view.

name: Monument Best view
description:
Close than other place.
No people during the day, some tourist come for photo but less than other panoramic point.
I Camped with tent, one of my favourite place in 2 years travelling.
Good also for car.

name: Mexican Hat UT Fantastic 360 view
description: Down a road past the abandoned fruit stand.  Gorgeous view of monuments & expansive space across Moab area.

name: Hite
description: dump station and potable water for free behind the gas station

name: Wild camp on canyon rim
description:
Beautiful wild camp spots on the north canyon rim!
Some shade from trees and rock overhangings.

the entrance is on the north east of the nearby bridge. The track goes under the bridge and through the dry riverbed, so a 4WD with high clearance is recommended. No problems with my motorcycle.

name: Tear Drop Arch B&B
description:
The owner allows camping on her property for $10 per night. Showers are $5 per person, and a breakfast is available for $7 a person. The views of Monument Valley are spectacular! It is critical to contact the host before arriving to make sure she can accommodate you, and To pay attention to their advertise directions as Google maps will take you on a 4WD only road. See photo for directions.

Bathroom and shower are in the home of the host. Camping surface is a very fine red sand, a few inches deep. We really enjoyed staying here, and would return in a heartbeat. Going to bed with a moonrise, and waking up with the sunrise over the monuments was a wonderful memory. There is hiking behind the B&B.

description: Nice turnout on unpaved road that's accessible without a 4x4. There are two spots within 200 feet and both are easy to back in to. Great views and good hiking around the area (no trails). As soon as the sun went down a lot of mosquitoes showed up but otherwise a great spot.

name: Hog Spring Recreation Area
description: Hog Spring Recreation Area. The spot is a pull out with room for a couple of larger RVs along Highway 95. Although it’s along the road at night there is virtually no traffic. It will work for one night.

name: Upper Browns Creek
description: Remote spot in the shadow of Mt. Pennell, with expansive views down NE to the area around the Dirty Devil River. Spot is grassy with a rocky knoll providing some morning shade and wind protection. Access to this area requires driving up the rocky Coyote Benches Road, so a higher clearance vehicle with good tires is recommended. This is a lonely area so you'll likely have it to yourself. No cell service. Water may be available early season just to the NW beside an old corral on Browns Creek.

name: Tire shop
description: Tire shop is located at the 2 story house on the dirt road, past  the Monument Valley KOA (uses the same road as KOA).  Trevan was able to fit our trailer and get us back on the road.  ‭ (928) 714-8442‬

name: White Canyon rim
description: Beautiful sites directly at the rim of the white canyon. You can stay at the parking lot (used by hikers) or go down the dirt road and even cross the wash. But therefore you need 4x4 and high clearance. The road is getting better after the wash.

name: Tucked away hideout in the canyon
description:
This is a really beautiful spot right off the road(300’ dirt rd) in a very beautiful spot of the canyon, right near hogwash recreation area. 

There is a fire pit in the creek bed as well as near a large rock. Private and tucked away when you park van  in back(we have 21’ class b). We put our screen tent in the front area near large rock and parked the van in the back for extra privacy. This is a great long term spot. No sprint or T-Mobile service

name: waaay out there
description: 30 minute off-road drive, any truck or suv is fine. Little sandy. Epic camp spot. No neighbors for 30ish minutes. Park on cliffs.

name: Bullfrog Ferry, Lake Powell
description: small RORO ferry from Bullfrog to Halls Crossing. Charge starts at  $25 p/car.  Last crossing departs 5pm.  We paid $43 for our truck 27ft long, 2 adults 2 kids.

name: Bullfrog Laundromat
description:

----------------------


Laundromat near store. Free showers also.  $1.00  to wash and 50 cents to dry

name: West of Blanding

name: Muley Point
description: This area is full of great wild camp options but this is one of our favorites even though the secret seems to be out so you will probably not be alone. It can get windy up here but the views are unbeatable. Only amenity here is fire pits. For an unforgettable drive, head north off the 163 through the valley of the gods (road turns off 7.5 miles north of Mexican Hat) on your way here. Roads in are dirt and not suitable for huge rigs.

name: Muley Point
description: Several nice spots here with great views. Super flat, awesome views, great rock fire pits. No facilities. Most spots accessible with 2wd. Not to be missed!

name: Bear Pooh Overlook
description: Looking for a free spot with a great view? Don't mind a little leveling, or possibly sharing the spot with some fury brown friends? This spot could be for you. Just off Forest Service road, fire pit, and has a GREAT view of the Utah landscape(hoodoos, etc). Not too far from Natural Bridge National Monument and kinda on the way to Canyonlands NP.

name: Recapture Reservoir
description:
This site is located north of Blanding on a small Lake and has approximately 4-5 sites along the lake whitout any facilities.
Camping possible on north and south shore of the lake.

Very quiet.

name: Monument Valley's best view

name: Kane Gulch Ranger Station

name: Lost cave rocks
description: Huge roundabout circle with several camping spots. Opposite of the valley you will see a huge cave that used to be the home of Indians. Worth the little walk. Absolutely peacefully place. Stayed here with my motorbike. Easy access.

name: Maverick gas in convenient store
description: Look for the red water pipe. The dump station is in the parking lot where the semi tractor-trailers park. On the downhill side of the gas station.

name: Switchback on FS 093
description: Just as you begin to transition from trees to Desert (or desert to trees if going uphill) on FS 093, there is a nice flat section of slick rock sandwiched in the switchback. With fire ring and 2 Verizon bars. 4WD only, and even then, if it rains, you might want chains. Good view.

name: Peace Tree - Monticello
description: Overlanders need quality coffee & food for those long highway stretches between routes in remote country.  The Peace Tree in Monticello is one of the best.  Great food, spectacular espresso & friendly folks help get you on into the backcountry of SE Utah.

name: Sierra Petroleum
description: Dirt lot next to highway (quiet at night) flat-ish ok for overnight parking.

name: Point Turn Off
description: Beautiful overlook just west of Salvation Point. 4x4 if wet, high clearance vehicle is a good idea. Large vehicle will have some problems turning around. It’s not a pull through. Amazing view of valley! One of my favorite locations so far!

name: Maverick gas station parking
description: Next to the dump there is a truck parking, clean and for big Rv. At the shop I was told to park for overnight near the white fence. No truck idling, but generators may be used during the night.

name: Four Corners
description: North side of highway, access road to private property (gated). Dirt track immediately turns west off the highway and away from the gate. Fairly flat, no signs prohibiting overnight parking and away from car headlights. Awesome panoramic views. Traffic is pretty minimal at night. Good place to hang for the night if you arrive at Four Corners Monument.

name: Bluff Public Library
description: Very strong & free wifi, you can drive thru...

name: Valley of the gods
description: Big area with 2 firerings for a lot of vans & rigs. In the evening we had strong winds. Leveled and nice surrounding & views.

name: Water point out front of the 7-11 fuel stop.
description: Fuel station, convince mart and water point

name: This Rocks!
description: Valley of the Gods. Wawie!! Incredible views. A little away from the main road. Crazily beautiful.

name: Laundromat & Shower
description:
Laundromat & Shower at Blanding RV Park.

Pay for the showers at the 7eleven. It's 5 Dollars + Tax per person. You get the door code when you pay. Amazing hot showers. 

Didn't use the Laundromat because it was very full on sunday.

name: Visitor Center
description:
Visitor Center of Blanding

Restrooms and WIFI are always open.
BlandingVC
Visitor Center is closed on sundays.

You can get water here for free. Bring your hoose or fill up canisters. You'll get the key in the visitor Center if you ask nicely.

No Overnight Camping here.

name: Valley Overlook, Birch Canyon Road
description: Nice campsite along Birch Canyon Road close to Natural Bridges National Monument. Pretty level site for a small campervan with firepit and trees around. Nice overlook over the valley. Sometimes windy. No cell service.

name: Rooster Camp
description: Among the best sites in the Valley of the Gods. Decent cell signal here. My personal fave.

name: Valley of the Gods
description:
Flat area off main road. No trees or cover but some hills may provide some wind barriers. No fire ring as fires are not allowed in VotG. About 2 miles from Hey 163.
Fantastic view of sunset and surrounding canyons.
We are travelling from Monument Valley to Four Corners and this is a great free place to camp along the lines of way.

name: Maverick Point
description: A gorgeous wild camping site with fire ring overlooking the valley, a few miles from the summit of Bear’s Ears on Forest Road 88.

name: Sinclair gas station
description: Free potable water available from a pump on the east side of the building.

name: Butler Wash, Wolfman Panel Trailhead
description:
Parking for 2, maybe 3, cars or small campervans. Beautiful 360° view. Short, easy hike down to the petroglyphs. There are 2 portable toilets about 50 metres away, on the main road beside the information kiosk. No other amenities. 

NPR at 88.1.

name: Butler Wash, Double Stack Ruin Trailhead
description:
Easy access from the main road. Parking for maybe 3 cars or small vans. For sure you will have a quiet night out here. No amenities. Nada. 

NPR at 88.1.

name: Butler Wash, Monarch Cave Trailhead
description:
Room for maybe 6 cars / small vans. Two nice clean portable toilets out by the road - about 50 metres away. The toilets are courtesy of the Friends Of Cedar Mesa - to discourage people from crapping in the woods. Or, as the sign says, to minimize visitor impact. No other amenities. 

Beware of significant water erosion in the parking area - especially if arriving after dark. 

NPR at 88.1.

name: San Juan County Library - Wifi
description: Much better wifi here than at the Visitors Center and no password. Works great in the parking lot behind the building.

name: Off 261
description: Wild campsite 2.5 miles from the hey on the right.

name: Cottonwood RV Park
description: Some shade good showers reasonable pricing $26 for no hookups for us. Same as the State Parks are charging.

name: National forest (secluded)
description: Nice private spot, GPS didn’t recognize some roads, so when you see the houses, split right down the fire road. The other two options are private drives. 4WD not need when dry, SUV or van is fine. There are a few streams, one only a short distance from this site, I can hear it. Might be seasonal. Some views of cliffs through the tress. Lots of trails for bike or ATV  2-3 bars AT&T and Verizon. Slow upload.

name: BLM-Monticello/Valley of the Gods
description: Called BLM- Monticello. This is a large turnout on the corner of Hwy 261 & Valley of the Gods Rd. before the road gets really windy. This road (Hwy 261) is safe for large trailers and 5th wheels up to this point. You cannot go further than this intersection with a trailer or large Class A. This area will accommodate at least 3-4 large RVs. It's a good site to overnight camp at if you'd like to unhook and take your small vehicle and explore the area. Will work for several small RVs as well.

name: Hammond Canyon Trailhead
description: A couple nice campsites just east (downhill) of the Hammond Canyon Trailhead. Both are under a Ponderosa Pine canopy and the lower one features a nice view over Hammond Canyon and the Abajo Mountains. The whole area (Elk Ridge) features dozens of dispersed camping spots and offers a great respite from the heat lower down in the summer months. Lower spot is slanted so may be less suitable for bigger rigs without leveling. Only an hour to Natural Bridges NM to the south. Verizon LTE as well.

name: Mexican Hat BLM by the river
description: This place is an oven in the summer. Don't let the name fool you; miserable hot. There are many sites here along the water. This one is surely among the least comfortable. Seemed like it would only be 4WD to here, but of course a minivan trundled by later in the day.

name: Indian creek wild camp
description: This is a dirt parking lot I have used before for a overnight with a Sprinter van camp, there is a rock lined campfire ring pretty flat. Off the road about 100' with bushes kind of hiding it.

name: Valley of the Gods
description: there are a few fire pits along this short road.

name: Looking at Mexican Hat
description: Large spot along river looking at Mexican Hat.  Fire pit.  4 bars Cell service.  Big rigs can fit on this spot, but probably wouldn’t chance the road coming in as there is a steepish hill with a sharp turn.  We are towing a motorcycle trailer and got in fine.

name: Pines Land
description:
Spacious pine forest in the Manti-LaSal NF. 
This particular spot is next to a creek bed. It is dry right now (as are most water spots), but must be lovely when running. 
Great place for kids and pets. Can see mountains through the trees. Accessible with 2WD when dry. 
Not one soul has passed by in 12+ hours. We did hear an ATV in the distance.
One bar ATT. Slow uploads but good for minimal stuff. 
Many spots in the NF. This is just one of them. 
*Please be respectful to the earth and your neighbors by taking your trash with you.*

name: Multiple secluded campsites
description:
FR0082 starts off nice and groomed but hits a chunky hill just before this camp.  The location of this pin will require high clearance, but there were a dozen other spots before the  rough patch. The road continues, and seems to be rather smooth, though it's not shown on google maps. I saw at least one more site before turning back to this one.  There's a good size grassy clearing behind it that would likely be good for some tents.

I drive a 2WD extended van with some off road tires.  If the rocks scare you, stay down the hill.  I had no problems but I do this sort of thing all the time.

name: San Juan County Library
description: WiFi can be accessed if you park near the handicapped spaces

name: Blanding Utah State 95
description: I moved here, just outside Blending. Very quiet place, vast and flat. Opportunity to barbecue by bringing your equipment

name: Valley of the gods outlook
description: Large site with fire pit that has expansive views but is exposed to winds

name: Warren Allen Loop Rd
description: Dispersed camping north of Utah State Route 95. A little hard to find on the road but when driving west, it'll be a small turnoff on the right. Spots scattered along the way on the loop, some with fire rings. Quiet and secluded but can be windy since it's exposed. At&t 3 bars

name: Valley of the Gods
description: Valley of the Gods is one of the most beautiful BLM areas I think in the country. The fact that is hasn’t turned into a national park is astonishing. I could live here in my van. 10/10. This site was part of bears ears but is now BLM. no campfires allowed. no services.

name: San Juan River - Swinging Bridge
description:
Saw what looked like the remnants of a foot bridge near here. This is on the bluffs on the north side of the river. We were the only ones there the night we camped. Gorgeous views, very quiet.
To get there, highway 191 north turn right onto 162, which follows the river. Just before mile marker 3 there is a cattle guard and dirt road going to a broad bluff off to the right. A loop road appears very quickly on your left taking you out to the campsite on the bluff edge. Only room for 3 or so large rigs out there.

name: 180’ view, Valley o t Gods
description: Holly crap it’s beautiful here.  Totally worth the effort.  Large enuf to turn around our 27ft truck. Used rocks to level. Majestic views, sunset is gorgeous!

name: Newspaper Rock Petroglyphs
description: The first emojis. 2,000 years of petroglyph carvings. Paved road. Pit toilet. Hiking there too. Must see!

name: Mule Canyon US95 west of Blanding Utah
description: Just off the road open spot free. 3 bars of slow Verizon. Some traffic noise but quiet at night. Sandy, no bugs. Good enough for an overnight. Near entrance to Mule Canyon.

name: Blanding Utah Recapture Reservoir
description:
Going north out of Blanding, the second road to the left just past the reservoir. Open, reasonably flat, some fire rings, next to water. Unreliable Verizon. It's okay, nice to have water nearby. There is some traffic noise but quiet at night. Across the reservoir are several big rigs. On this side, big rigs may have trouble. The access road is the old highway and is higher than the surrounding. Free. We saw one picnic table and one portable toilet. 

A short swimming distance from the north shore there's a rock that's fun to climb on to ana jump off into the water 😀

name: Among the short Pines just off 261 near Natural Bridges NM
description: Old Jeep trail off 261 going South, entrance is a diagonal trail that takes off to the West. Drove in about 1/2 mile, secluded and flat

name: Access trail to Wild Camping near Natural Bridges NM
description: Remote trail accessible by 2x, good view of Bears Ears. A few flat areas for 1 or 2 vehicles

name: Top of Moki Dugway
description: Great spot at the top of Moki Dugway. You can walk right from camp to a great view of valley of the gods. Suitable for vans, truck campers or similarly sized rigs. Room for 2 at the pin. No useable Verizon or T-Mobile even with booster and antenna.

name: BLM road 4524
description:
Large, flat pullout off of BLM road 4524 just before the creek ford. Located about a mile from the state line on County Road G, about 12 miles past the Sand Canyon Trailhead in Canyons of the Ancients NM. 
No shade. I had between one and three bars for ATT cell service. Some intermittent road noise, but otherwise I had a couple very peaceful nights here.

name: Harts Draw
description: Great spot on Harts Draw overlooking the mountains. A bar or two of Verizon LTE. Amazing views of the mountains and cliffs

name: Johnson Creek
description: A clearing by the river near the road. Probably used mostly by hunters and herding cowboys in the area. Has a fire pit and a small creek. As I’m writing this, a bear is busy eating our table which I foolishly left outside! Apparently, there’s plenty of wildlife around. So watch out...

name: Coyote
description: Beautiful spot. Fire ring and level. Room for 2 vehicles. Just off spur from Beef Basin Rd. Great 360" views of mountains & canyons. 2+ mi from ruins. No cell.

name: Long Point
description: Small spot with fire ring in ponderosa pine forest. Not far from incredible views of Dark Canyon, Beef Basin and Canyonlands NP.

name: BLM Wild Camping
description: BLM area off dirt road. Plenty of room for pull-thru and turnaround of large rigs/trailers. Fire pit in center. Generally level ground in some spots.

name: Edge Of The World
description: We parked right along the edge of the Mesa, looking down over 1000 ft into Monument Valley. Most spectacular campsite of our lives.

name: Truck crash site
description: Great spot overlooking Hammond Canyon.  Far enough off main road to be very quiet.  No Verizon service.  We got our 2 wheel drive van back here, but the road is more suited to high clearance and 4 wheel drive vehicles.  If you look over the cliff you will see a surplus WW2 truck, random axles and one 1950's car.  Loved it.

name: No-Mans Island Camp
description: Beautiful desolate camp.  We saw no one the whole time.  Even the critters didn't seem to know how to deal with people.  We had a toad feast under our artificial light.   No Verizon service.  We took our two wheel drive van, but if it rains, 4 wheel drive is necessary.

name: Abajo Flat National Forest
description: Nice little hidden location with great views at the end of a short forestry road.

name: Newspaper Rock Parking Area
description: Parking lot at Newspaper Rock. There are no signs that say 'no overnight camping'. There were several other vans parked here with me. No cell service.

name: Outside Blanding
description: This BLM spot is 4 miles outside Blanding on Warren Allen road. There are a few campsites along the way. 2 bars of Verizon. Little bit of highway noise but pulled in around 11pm and didn’t see anyone else. My GPS on my phone may be throwing me off the path a bit

name: K2 peaceful dispersed camping
description: Love this spot, tall scattered pines with views in between. Quiet. Coyotes singing at dusk. Flat, large enough for 10 cars. Good cell service.  Plenty of hiking. Just Beautiful.  Dirt road in, no issues.

name: San Juan River - Big Rigs
description: So this is a large flat area before you go down the hill closer to the river. Granted, the place down the hill closer to the river is drop-dead gorgeous. But I wouldn't recommend it for trucks pulling trailers. I think full size class C's would be fine. But I'd stay up top here if you're in a longer rig.

name: Mesa verde Nationalpark (outside In BLM)
description:
Close to the entrence of mesa verde nationalpark, on a dirtroad more then one spot for free with firering. In the park by the store are laundrys with coins, showers for free and fast wifi.

From Hwy 160, get off at MC RD 34, then a few hundred metres, turn right at the first gravel road. Good secluded sites, a bit noisy from highway but it gets quiet after 9 pm. Some sites showed signs of overuse and garbage was left. One site looked like it had been used extensively by "travelers", with garbage bags left at the site. Lots of coyotes around. Note that showers and laundromat inside the NP are closed for the winter.

3 bars Verizon signal with LTE.
No bars AT&T

name: Ancient Cedars @ Mesa Verde RV Resort
description: A very good site with all facilities and warm bathrooms, a great treat when travelling in early spring. Approx 30 dollars for 2 depending on what sort of hook up required. Site just across the road from the entrance to Masa Verde National Park.

description: A little way east of Mancos, forest road 316 heads north, also called Madden Peak Rd. The first mile or so goes thru private property, then it enters the national forest. There are scattered boondocking locations in the next few miles of the road. If you take a right into FR 568, there are also a couple of spots there.

name: Am Doloresriver
description:
Very nice places at the brook


Sehr schöne Plätze am Bach

name: San Juan National Forest off FR 316
description: Nice area full of good campsites with fire rings. Sites closer to the entrance had a few hunters so we continued up the road to the mountain to this nice and sheltered site. Road is good without 4x4 when dry.

name: Canyons of the Ancients National Monument
description: Don't be fooled by the road to get there, it's a real maze so use google maps. Access is through private farm lands and you might think you will be camping with the cows. But soon you will reach the access road to this magnificent natural forest. Sites are few, but have fire rings. By far my favourite spot to camp. A real gem.

name: Southern Section of Canyon of the Ancients NM
description: Off the main road through gate. 2 km private road then BLM land. Nice spot road a bit rough.

name: Canyons of the Ancients off MC BB
description: Great site a few hundred metres from Anasazi ruins. Fire ring, flat spot, great view. Very quiet, a few visitors were at the ruins during the day but all left before 18:00. From Cortez, drive north on 491, turn left at MC BB (MC roads are named A B C D, etc. BB comes after Z, then AA). Drive 6 miles on BB, turn left on 10. Drive for 11.3 miles then turn left unto a high clearance dirt road for about a mile, then you get to a small parking area. The camp site is nearby. A few miles further is the Cutthroat ruins. Breathtaking! The road there is very rough and requires a high clearance 4x4.

name: Bay city camp ground
description: Beautiful view camping along the creek. Site had a fire ring but lots of trash. Obviously a place for high school parties

name: Rico Dolores River
description: A large space between the road and the river. right on county line marker

name: Dolores - San Juan Nf
description:
Nice spot everywhere during 2mi with fire pit 
no services 
road paved at 200ft 
(campground 14 days free )

name: Canyon of the Ancients NM
description:
Amazing view!!!
In BLM managed NM. Free. 
Access via dirt road. High clearance 2WD is no problem (we have a VW vanagon).
...amazing view. Google maps gets you to the left turn onto BLM. See sign.
(It's 1 mile past the trailhead on the left.)

name: Mancos State Park Campground
description: Great camping at the Mancoa State Park, $18 camping, $7 parking fees. camp sites have gravel, restrooms are super clean (pit toilet). Park ranger bis very nice and comes around a few times a day. Recommend..

name: Cherry Creek Gravel Pit
description: Great pull-out for a quick stop or for a few days of exploring around Durango. We stopped here in route to Moab and would definitely stay here again. Several rigs showed up later in the evening, but it was quiet and peaceful. Plenty of down wood if conditions are good for a fire. There was unfortunately a few mule deer carcasses that had been dropped there, but that is expected with spots so close to the highway.

name: Shower - Rec Center

name: By the river in San Juan NF
description: Nice spot on the cottonwood road  directly at the river in the San Juan National Forest. Flat area, existing firering. Very quiet at night (you hear only the river). Road is not maintained until May 15th but is in very good condition. Free.

name: Roads closed during winter season
description: Forest Road 611 and Dunten Road (9 Mile connection to State Highway 145) are both closed during winter season. Opens at earliest May 15th (depending how much snow is still on the pass). We had to turn around

name: La Mesa RV Park
description: Nice quiet RV Park. Has showers, two restrooms, 36 or so RV spots. Has Laundry room on site. Has heater in very clean restrooms with multiple showers. Located next to a Conoco Gas station with Car wash. The RV park has hookups from what I can tell. Very clean and offers picnic tables.

name: La Plata Campground
description: Nice place to camp, we have a 27ft Travel Trailer and was able to get down the path and in a spot right next to the river. There is nothing like hearing a flowing river to rock you to sleep. They have fire pits available, but no trash, please pack out what you pack in. Side note, please use designated camping areas on the road due to the amount of private land in the area.

name: Ute Mountain Travel Center
description: Has everything you could need for a night stop. Food, laundry, showers, sauna, pool, full plug-in sites, tent sites, gas, truck stop, hotel/casino, and more. Clean and comfortable. Very responsible in price.

name: Cahone Park
description: Public park of the small town of Cahone, next to the highway. Lots of leveled grass, some picnic tables and barbecues and a pit toilet in the back. The water faucet didn't work unfortunately. No "no camping" posted. Good spot for a night.

name: Free site #5
description: Drive a little bit past the coordinates, and the turn is on the right. Site is clearly marked with a (5). Other remote campers nearby, but still felt very private and secluded with all the trees. Some phone service. Recommend!

description: Established RV Resort with full hookups, laundry, and showers. It was $52/night for us, but there is a Good Sam discount.  Close to Mesa Verde.

name: boggy trail
description: Multiple sites easy two-wheel entry trailhead

name: San Juan NF
description:
Great open space. No water. RV friendly. 
Visited early spring. Still lots of snow, mud, swampy areas. Many other roads still closed. Found this spot. No one else around. No wifi. No water.

name: Conoco
description: we stopped to get fuel and asked if we could get water from the spigot outside and throw our trash bag away and was very nice and said it was OK

name: Beautiful camp spot
description: Campsite by a creek. Best time is fall , surrounded by Aspen and lush grass. Great is spring and summer too. Keep in mind the road is maintained from May  to October. Also a great spot to camp near hike bike Mavresso trail 204

name: Camp and Hike
description: Beautiful spot , with a cement pad and fire pit  Aspen and lush grass. Then hike  or bike Maveresso Trail 204 : which is a 5.8 mile

name: Black Bear liquor
description: very nice lady just ask and they will let you get water and throw your trash away

name: Showers at Ute Travel Plaza
description: Showers with free wifi. Just about everything you need here

name: San Juan national forest rd 316
description: Hundreds of spots all along forest rd 316. It’s easy 2 wd for the first several miles. Gets a little hairy after second cattle guard. I did no problem in my low clearance front wd minivan. Even past third cattle guard but I wouldn’t venture down the steep hill 3/4 m past Cattle guard 3 without high clearance and or 4x4 noticeably cooler at9800 ft. Please take trash with you when you leave and responsibly bury your poo big rigs will have trouble after second cattle guard. Go slow..

name: Roadside Respite
description: Turn downhill in front of yellow/black road turn sign.  3-4 spots with fire rings.  Between the road and the river, so you can hear both.  No cell service.  Some shaded, some not.  Road in is bumpy and uneven, not recommended for a long load.

name: Field of Daisies off 44
description: San Juan national forest, little lane off 44 leads to gorgeous pullout with daisies (mid June) and aspens, breezes and cicadas, scrub oak and a VIEW. Had to level slightly. Fire ring, for when that’s in season. Two bars Att lte

name: Sleeping UTE RV Park
description: Tent sites, pull though RV sites, picnicing areas, etc. All sites have a picnic table and BBQ grill (no fire rings). Looks like RV sites have water/power hookups. The showers were very clean and nice. The pool/sauna was closed due to Covid (even at the casino hotel). we came in at 9:15pm in peak season and got a tent spot without a problem. They offer AAA and Good Sam discounts as well. There was some road noise and a few cars drove through with headlights after 10pm but it was okay for a tent camp for a night. Views were nice as well. Sprinklers came on near tent sites (got tent a little wet) at 4am. Free WiFi as well. Free coffee in the office in AM as well. Some camping/RV items for sale in office too.

name: San Juan road 316
description: As described in earlier reviews - a campsite along the rout 316. This one is hard to find and the further you go along the road the fewer sites it seems like. But this one is a great spot, lots of good firewood, fire pit and a very dense forest around. Won’t fit in a big RV and wouldn’t recommend going that far on it anyway but our van fit perfectly well and the road was fine even after a small rain

name: Side of the road with a view
description: Large area to pull off the road for a spell. Plenty if space for a couple vehicles. Traffic is buzzing nearby.

name: Sante Fe Forest FR350
description: 100 yards off gravel road. Heavily wooded.

name: Sleeping Ute Mountain rest area
description: Bathrooms and water. There are only water fountains without the bottle fill spigots, but you can still fill small containers.

name: Mesa Verde NP Visitor Center
description: Water fill spigot by restrooms, you need to walk up to it from the parking lot. Before the National Park entrance gate so no fee/pass needed.

name: Cortez Plaza Shopping Center
description: This is an abandoned shopping center parking lot, don't know if overnight parking is okay but there are no signs prohibiting it. Plenty of space to park even for big rigs.

name: San Juan NF RD 350
description:
Lots of spots above 10000 feet secluded campsites lots of privacy and big tall pines 
Easy road. Little bumpy and might need 4x4 if heavy rain but low clearance okay! Easy in a minivan 
Two bars Verizon prepaid and pretty quiet except for a few four wheelers and such 
Please do your part and leave no trace.

name: truck stop
description: well lit. fairly quiet if parked in the back, next to the open field.

name: Cortez Industrial Park
description:
Water available at station, small building on left as you pull in. Large hose for tankers but there is a small hose hookup on side of building. 25 cents for 13 gallons of water.

There is also an RV dump station that is seasonal however it was closed when we were here so may not be available.

Multiple recycling containers also available but no trash dump.

name: Little Fish Creek
description: Sweet little site near little fish creek on the Colorado Backcountry discovery route. Very quiet no water, electrical or sewer. No toilets, (remember your wag bag). Site was very clean with a rock ground fire ring. Lots of trees to hang a hammock. Multiple sites nearby but far enough to not see or hear others. No cell signal

name: CR 316 // single camp spot along the road
description: While there are plenty of nice, spacious spots to camp in with vehicles of all sizes along the first mile or two or so of Forest Road 316, this exact spot is a few miles up the mountain, towards Madden Peak, where you’ll find more spots, but more they get more sparse as you drive up. This one is a very spacious spot with a firepit along the road. There are cars driving up and down the road all day, but really not that many. The reason I am posting this review though, is that I did see a bear here this morning. It walked away when I opened my car trunk, but just saying: they are here! So keeping a clean camp will probably help not attract them as much!

name: Fall Creek Road
description: Fall Creek Road about a mile down had a Fall Creek Road Recreation Area that you can camp at that has about 5-7 spots. Big rigs could fit if needed. I opted to stay about 1/4 mile down on the left and one spot tucked away by the river. Lots of pull offs on the road and was pretty quiet all night.

description: $2.50 per gallon, will fill onboard tank and has bottle exchanges.

name: San Juan NFS #258, Dolores, CO
description: At mp6, dirt road into beautiful tall ponderosa pines. Many sites with pine needles or lovely open green meadows, good for rigs of various sizes. May be impassable when wet. Past one mile turn around with trailer or motorhome may be very difficult. Very little traffic, quiet, projects an aura of stillness and peace. Unusable one bar of Verizon. Free, 10 minutes from Dolores where there is a strong signal. Great place just to walk or to read and relax!

name: McPhee Campground
description:
Pretty nice campground with good cellphone service. Winter rates are $12/night, no amenities except for a portapotty. In-season rates are higher but then there's electric, water and a dump station. 

Water spigots were scattered around the campground and many sites had electric hookups. However, everything is shut off during the off-season as previously mentioned.
